The Italian Supreme Court explained how DNA evidence should be assessed in 
court i.e. contamination must be proven with certainty not supposition. The 
burden of proof is on the person who asserts contamination, not the person 
who denies it. In other words, if the defence lawyers claim the DNA 
evidence was contaminated, they must describe the specific place and time 
where it could have plausibly occurred. Nobody has ever proved that the bra 
clasp and knife evidence were contaminated.

Dr Stefanoni analysed the traces on the knife six days after last handling 
Meredith’s DNA. This mean laboratory contamination can be ruled out. 

“Laboratory contamination was also excluded by these experts [Conti and 
Vecchiotti].” (The Supreme Court report, page 92).

Judge Micheli ruled out contamination during the collection phase because 
the knife was sequestered from Sollecito’s apartment on Corso Garibaldi by 
a different police team to the one that collected evidence from the cottage 
on Via della Pergola on the same day.

Meredith had never been to Sollecito’s apartment, so contamination away 
from the laboratory was impossible.

Professor Torricelli testified at the Massei trial that it was unlikely the 
clasp was contaminated because there was a significant amount of 
Sollecito's DNA on it. 

Alberto Intini, the head of the Italian police forensic science unit, 
excluded environmental contamination at the Massei trial because “DNA 
doesn’t fly.”

Professor Novelli also ruled out environmental contamination:

“The hook contaminated by dust? It’s more likely for a meteorite to fall 
and bring this court down to the ground.”

David Balding, a Professor of Statistical Genetics at University College 
London, analysed the DNA evidence against Sollecito and concluded it was 
strong: 

"But because Sollecito is fully represented in the stain at 15 loci (we 
still only use 10 in the UK, so 15 is a lot), the evidence against him is 
strong."

Crime scenes are not clean, sterilised environments like laboratories. If a 
forensic technician picks up a dusty object off the floor, they will get 
dust on their gloves. It's irrelevant anyway because it's impossible to get 
a full DNA profile from dust. In other words, Solicitors DNA couldn't have 
come from the small amount of dust on the glove. He claimed that he had 
never been in Meredith's room. What was the source of Sollecito's DNA? The 
Supreme Court pointed out that Sollecito’s DNA was never found alone at the 
cottage. The only trace of his DNA was mixed with Knox’s DNA on the 
cigarette butt in the kitchen. This means the mixed DNA sample could not 
have been the source of the DNA on the clasp because Knox’s DNA would also 
have been found on it. It's impossible that a forensic technician 
contaminated the bra clasp because tertiary transfer of touch DNA has never 
been demonstrated in a reliable, peer-reviewed scientific study.

The case against Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito has never hinged on the 
DNA evidence. 

Four witnesses, including two police officers, said there were shards of 
glass on top of the clothes on Filomena's floor. This proves the window was 
broken after the room had been ransacked and that the break-in was staged. 
It couldn't have been Rudy Guede because his bloody footprints led straight 
out of Meredith's room and out of the cottage. There was not one 
fingerprint, palm print, footprint, shoeprint, hair follicle, speck of DNA 
etc belonging to Guede in this room. Who staged the break-in? Here's a 
clue: Amanda Knox's DNA was found mixed with Meredith's blood on the floor 
of Filomena's room.

The bloody footprint on the blue bathmat in the bathroom matched the 
precise characteristics of Sollecito’s foot, but couldn’t possibly belong 
to Guede. Knox's and Sollecito's bare bloody footprints were revealed by 
Luminol in the hallway.

The computer and telephone records provide irrefutable proof that Knox and 
Sollecito lied repeatedly to the police. They gave completely different 
accounts of where they were, who they were with and what they were doing on 
the night of the murder. Neither Knox nor Sollecito have credible alibis

And so we go back to an original comment made some time ago: I wish people 
would stop using CSI Miami and the like as a benchmark for a murder 
investigation. DNA is not the epicentre of a murder investigation owing to 
the fact it only enables us to know who was where, who came into heavy 
contact with what etcetera. It cannot tell us what happened with any 
credible detail. It cannot re create a crime on it's own. It cannot 
determine a motive. It cannot tell us about the behaviour and state of mind 
of a suspect. It cannot even begin to help to explain complex interpersonal 
adolescent relationships, unless we only ever use 'semen' as our centre 
point. Something that ticks me off about the US stance on all of this is 
that by focusing strictly on DNA they have turned a blind eye to the wealth 
of all the other physical and testimonial evidence. I don't know how they 
do things in the US but in Europe, particularly France and Italy, they 
still use their instinct. Instinct is a detectives greatest asset. And DNA 
is useful in proving that the suspect was at the scene of the crime. That 
the suspect came into contact with the murder weapon. That the suspect came 
into contact with the victim. Lets look at the three primary suspects: 
1)Guede - contact with victim? Check. At the scene? Check. Contact with 
weapon? Check. 2)Knox - contact with victim? Neg. At the scene? Check. 
Contact with weapon? Check. 3)Sollecitto - Check Check Check. So where does 
that leave us? cherry picking one from three possibilities and discounting 
two? or does it mean we can determine that the three suspects were present 
when the crime was committed; therefore, utilizing the other physical and 
testimonial evidence we can determine that yes, all three are guilty. It is 
worthy to note that the evidence is rather compelling and in the US would 
be enough to deny an appeal. FOA forget how lucky Amanda was to have 
murdered someone in Italy and not back home in Seattle where the state 
still uses the death penalty.
